comments:
This course is an introduction to the visual arts including painting, sculpture, print culture, and new media such as photography, film, performance and installation art-in Europe and the United States from 1400 to the present. It offers a broad historical overview of the key movements and the artists of the period, as well as an investigation into the crucial themes and contexts that mark visual art production after the Middle Ages. Such themes include the secularization of art; the (gendered) role of the artist in society; the sites of art production and consumption such as the artist's studio, the royal courts and the art exhibition; the materials of art; the import of technology and science to art's making, content and distribution; the rise of art criticism; and the socio-political contexts of patronage and audience; among others.

Many students reported learning a lot from this course. The majority of students enjoyed the course and found that it is “one of the better survey classes… at Penn.” Students agreed it was a good class that was both interesting and informative. As one student noted, the course “enhances one’s cultural awareness of art.” Another student agreed, noting that “I came into [this course] knowing nothing about art history, and came out feeling that I now have a good handle on movements in art history.” Students also agreed that the course was engaging; “The information was exceptional and the material stimulating,” one student wrote. A couple of students, although, noted that the course covers many topics very broadly and therefore does not go in-depth on any specific period.

Students generally enjoyed Professor Silver’s teaching.  Professor Silver’s lectures were “great in introducing [and] analyzing monumental works throughout time.” Professor Silver “did a fantastic job covering art history over centuries.” In the overall scheme of the class, “Silver focused more on the paintings [themselves,]” one student noted. Although students found that Professor Silver was not as approachable or available, the TAs were able to compensate so that students felt there was a support system.  The majority of students agreed that Professor Silver was knowledgeable and “his lectures were… stimulating and interesting.”  According to student feedback, Professor Silver was also “knowledgeable, passionate, and enjoyable”

According to student feedback, the course is not overly difficult. As one student noted, this “course may lean a little on the easy side.” The difficulty of the course, many students found, came from the memorization of precise dates and the overall grand scope of the course and fast pace. Students also found that the writing assignments were “especially valuable” to understanding of course content. As computers are not allowed, many students found it difficult to keep up with the slides and found that note taking by hand was not quick enough to record all the information. Students would recommend this course to anyone independent of majors or interest. As a few students noted, “the course is absolutely essential for majors and highly recommended for non-majors.” A minority of students disagreed that the course should only be taken by students with an interest in art history; a few noted that the course was, at times, a bit difficult for people with no background in art history. This course satisfies the Arts & Letters Sector.

This course is an introduction to the visual arts including painting, sculpture, print culture, and new media such as photography, film, performance and installation art-in Europe and the United States from 1400 to the present. It offers a broad historical overview of the key movements and the artists of the period, as well as an investigation into the crucial themes and contexts that mark visual art production after the Middle Ages. Such themes include the secularization of art; the (gendered) role of the artist in society; the sites of art production and consumption such as the artist's studio, the royal courts and the art exhibition; the materials of art; the import of technology and science to art's making, content and distribution; the rise of art criticism; and the socio-political contexts of patronage and audience; among others.

Many students reported learning a lot from this course. The majority of students enjoyed the course and found that it is “one of the better survey classes… at Penn.” Students agreed it was a good class that was both interesting and informative. As one student noted, the course “enhances one’s cultural awareness of art.” Another student agreed, noting that “I came into [this course] knowing nothing about art history, and came out feeling that I now have a good handle on movements in art history.” Students also agreed that the course was engaging; “The information was exceptional and the material stimulating,” one student wrote. A couple of students, although, noted that the course covers many topics very broadly and therefore does not go in-depth on any specific period.

Student agreed that Professor Dombrowski was “intelligent and thoughtful” and also enthusiastic about the subject matter. One student noted that Professor Dombrowski’s lectures were “great in introducing [and] analyzing monumental works throughout time.” Although students found that Professor Dombrowski was not as approachable or available, the TAs were able to compensate so that students felt there was a support system. One student noted that, “Professor Dombrowski was very knowledgeable of the overall history and explained and focused on it more.” A few students also noted that Professor Dombrowski can be extremely engaging, albeit “overly theatrical [and] dramatic.” Student critique of Professor Dombrowski was limited to questions of organization, as one student commented, “Professor Dombrowski is too all over the place. Clearly, he is knowledgeable, but he does not teach very effectively. He is too difficult to follow and incredibly confusing,” making it harder to figure out what information is most important.

According to student feedback, the course is not overly difficult. As one student noted, this “course may lean a little on the easy side.” The difficulty of the course, many students found, came from the memorization of precise dates and the overall grand scope of the course and fast pace. Students also found that the writing assignments were “especially valuable” to understanding of course content. As computers are not allowed, many students found it difficult to keep up with the slides and found that note taking by hand was not quick enough to record all the information. Students would recommend this course to anyone independent of majors or interest. As a few students noted, “the course is absolutely essential for majors and highly recommended for non-majors.” A minority of students disagreed that the course should only be taken by students with an interest in art history; a few noted that the course was, at times, a bit difficult for people with no background in art history. This course satisfies the Arts & Letters Sector.
